title: How many New York City eviction filings will be reported for 2021?
preds:
State wide counts here, then listed by county: https://ww2.nycourts.gov/lt-evictions-33576
https://evictionlab.org/eviction-tracking/new-york-ny/
Looks like it'll end up around 42k. https://www.ryanbeckauthor.com/forecasting/New-York-Evictions.html
35,029 as of data updated on November 6
Evictions remain low and looks very likely they won't cross 60k https://www.ryanbeckauthor.com/forecasting/New-York-Evictions.html

Looks like it's likely the moratorium gets extended, though legal challenges are still possible. Narrowing in on lower numbers. https://www.thecity.nyc/housing/2021/8/30/22649435/new-york-eviction-moratorium-poised-for-months-long-extension

Nearly 500,000 households in New York City have rent arrears that collectively total more than $2.2 billion, according to an analysis of census data by the National Equity Atlas, a research group associated with the University of Southern California.
Modeled results, although I think my model isn't considering political factors enough. My inside view suggests these numbers are weighted too high.
-5 on over 240k, that seems unlikely as it would be massively over historical trends and rental assistance should push down the possibility of a huge jump when the moratorium ends.

26,212 through August 9th. The big wildcard here is what happens when the moratorium ends (either by court order or non-renewal). Either way, the numbers should stay under 1,000 per week through September. Then, either the numbers will return to an average year (landing us in bin 2) or we see a spike in evictions (likely putting us in bin 3). I don't see much of a chance that the moratorium lasts through the end of the year (needed to get bin 1). I also can't image a huge flood of backlogged evictions bringing us into a normal year (bin 4). It seems even less likely that such a backlog floods the system with an entire year's worth of paperwork during the last quarter (bin 5).

Today, the Supreme Court blocked part of New York's eviction moratorium. The order applies to a provision that bars evictions of tenants who file a form declaring economic hardship, rather than provide evidence in court (NYT).
"It's not clear how many people could be immediately affected. More than 830,000 households in New York State, the majority of them in NYC, are behind on rent, with a total estimated debt of more than $3.2 billion" The report in the NYT quotes a state senator who says it appears landlords could start filing suits immediately to evict tenants. But a patchwork of other state and federal protections remains in place that could stop their suits from succeeding, including the CDC eviction moratorium which includes all of NYC.  
About $100 million, or less than 4% of the state's $2.7 billion total has been spent from federal relief dollars given to NYS.(NYT)
 The money is there, it's a matter of the state and city getting it together to process applications. I know they are offering grants to non profits to start processing applicants but those are themselves scrambling to get staffing and trained them.
The CDC extension to Oct really cuts the chances of the higher bins. I'm heavily weighting the second bin due to the chance that the moratorium really does end at some point.

https://www.nydailynews.com/coronavirus/ny-covid-cdc-eviction-moratorium-extended-20210803-zjcn5xxlv5eltmzn5ixz7bdwwi-story.html Weekly eviction rate has already dropped below 1000 from a high of about 1500 in early May, and with the extension of the eviction moratorium to October 3 (and applying to all of NYC), we may not see even 60k.

The 2020 number is a poor base rate, given the moratorium during most of the year. The average from the data file for prior years is 223k, or about 19k per month. So, a simple exercise of YTD (23,596) plus the average for the remaining five months gets you to 116,590. This seems like the most appropriate starting place. However, a look at the data for 2020 before COVID (through March 15) reveals that near term numbers were already 30% below average. This leads me to wonder if the base rate values are inflated.  Now, we have to consider to factors. First, is there a backlog of evictions that will be filed next month leading to much higher than average values for the rest of the year? Second, will there be political intervention at a city level for the rest of the year? The second question likely has some dependence on the first. For example, a flood of evictions in September would overwhelm the courts and prompt cries for help - thus increasing the odds that another intervention strategy goes into effect. Therefore, I can see a feedback mechanism holding down the probability of greater than normal values.  I'm not convinced that the city would intervene at a rate that will keep numbers at the very low level we have seen so far this year, but I am surprised the crowd has discounted the possibility to zero. I also see no reason to believe that the system will more than double a normal year during the back half of this one. While I understand the potential for a flood of backlogged cases to push us into bin 4, I don't see potential for the year to end up 110% of a normal year.

I put together some figures and data tables from the source data here: https://www.ryanbeckauthor.com/forecasting/New-York-Evictions.html The 2012-2016 average would put a typical year in the ballpark of around 200 to 225k evictions. Figure 2 of this link provided by @jleibowich  is in the ballpark of that as well and provides additional info on the trend [1]. In 2020 there were 74k and year to date in 2021 is at 22k, with a current pace of about 10k every two months which would put it at around 50k at the end of the year if the trend continued. But the eviction moratorium in NY ends August 31. So there is definitely potential for eviction filings to jump up. However, rental relief (which has been slow to get out) is starting to be distributed [2], which I think lowers the potential for evictions somewhat after the moratorium. I'm thinking the low end scenario is one where either the eviction moratorium in New York is extended, or rental relief goes out on time and cuts down the number of evictions after the moratorium ends, either of which could put total eviction filings in 2021 a little above or below 60k. I think the high end scenario is one where evictions jump up to double the 2012-2016 trend after August 31 for the remainder of the year, which would put it around 8,000 evictions per week for about 18 weeks, putting the year end total around 170k. Based on that I'm giving about a 55% chance of evictions staying under 120k for the year. The higher numbers also have larger bucket sizes, so I've given more weight to larger buckets accordingly as well. The CDC eviction moratorium ends July 31 (and also appears to have been struck down in court) so I'll be watching what happens in other states here [3] to see what we might expect in New York after the moratorium expires. Additionally this Vox article [4] has lots of good information [4]. [1] https://furmancenter.org/stateofthecity/view/eviction-filings [2] https://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/news/2021/07/22/new-york-rent-relief-program-eligibility-application-payment-landlords/8048166002/ [3] https://evictionlab.org/eviction-tracking/ [4] https://www.vox.com/22429430/renters-rent-relief-eviction-moratorium-housing-market

A federal court on Friday ruled that the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) overstepped its authority by halting evictions during the COVID-19 pandemic. The Cincinnati-based U.S. Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals unanimously agreed (pdf) with a lower court ruling that said the CDC engaged in federal overreach with the eviction moratorium, which the agency has consistently extended for months. Several weeks ago, the CDC announced it would allow the policy, which was passed into law by Congress, to expire at the end of July.

Can explain how to SUM the Actual data we have so far?  Or share a summary? I don't understand how to manipulate the CSV file.
In the meantime, I expect to be way higher than 2020, so will start 20, 60, 20 on the high categories.
Between covid economic fallout and the number of people that just stopped paying after leaving the city, the number is going to go up a lot.
people should be allowed to stay in their homes it’s the humane course of action unless you are truly evil. prison is no substitute either. Most people in prisons are political prisoners.

There were 35.8k evictions in 2020 before the eviction moratorium (about 416/day), and about 38.5k evictions between the start of the moratorium and the end of the year (about 137/day). Based on the 2021 filings up to and including the week of June 20th, there have been about 113/day. Assuming all of the evictions that didn't happen between March 27, 2020 and now ended up in a backlog, there are currently about 130k pending evictions. With the moratorium lifting at the end of July, I would many of these go through notwithstanding rental assistance programs and the like. E.g. https://www.thecity.nyc/2021/6/27/22551078/new-york-rent-relief-application-frustrate-landlords-tenants On top of regular evictions that would've taken place without COVID, there would also be evictions due to job losses as a result of COVID. Let's say 2 person households on average, so about 300k potential evictions due to unpaid rent.
https://www.thecity.nyc/economy/2021/3/14/22326414/nyc-lost-record-jobs-to-pandemic-unemployment Assuming 20% of these combined evictions-to-be are not acted on this year, 20% received rental relief in time to prevent an eviction filing, and the other 60% are file (no particular reason for these numbers), we get... 277k. Whew. That said, I have made many assumptions about backlogs, rental relief, landlords, and so on, without particular reasoning behind them. Maybe the relief programs will run smoothly and hand out adequate cash, maybe landlords will be more patient, etc.

The new extension was granted in part as owners say federal funds to help people pay back rent is available but it is not being disbursed quickly enough.  The city needs to help expedite the application process and ease requirements in terms of documentation (other state-funded programs for rent relief last year were said to only have approved 15% of applications, they had to reopen the application period a few months later and review all applications that had been denied. State reps and community orgs said the application was requiring too many documents that were difficult for people to get in the middle of the pandemic). As for pre-pandemic numbers, for comparison, there 230,071 eviction petitions filed by building owners at New York City Housing Court  in 2017.  (Only 9% of them, or 20,804 evictions were executed by the City Marshall). This shows that the city does scramble to solve the issue in court instead of using preventative methods or acting early to assist in cases that may not be complicated or for which there are feasible solutions.  The city has indeed been scrambling since the pandemic and can barely keep up with housing issues. Nonprofit orgs that offer legal assistance are overwhelmed. The mayor's office opened a tenant assistance unit but hard to tell if there is more hiring/expansion of staff there or at nonprofits to help with the volume of cases. 
One would assume that landlords are more likely to try to work things out if they know the funds are available for them to get paid than spend legal fees. A new mayor and city council won't take office til January 1 so it's somewhat predictable that the Di Blasio admin won't change course under pressure of reelection. Landlords need to get paid and the money is available to help in the overwhelming majority of cases, the issue is how quickly and efficiently can the city manage the backlog. It's getting better but it's still pretty messy.
Another note, the relatively low number of filings so far this year may be related to courts being closed, also many people were working from home and everything government related seemed to have been taking 4-6 times as long to get done. 
Also interesting is the range in numbers in the question, I often find that telling so will for now side with there is a lot of money to fix this problem, it will get expedited and a tsunami of filings greater than the usual for the city will be avoided. The crisis was averted so far... Will have to watch how it develops, they either fix it or let it rip badly. 
https://council.nyc.gov/data/evictions/
https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/16/business/affordable-housing-crisis.html
Based on my observation, we will have at least 2x the current eviction filings from 2020.
